metadata.author: Claude (Opus Web)
metadata.purpose: ATLAS voice assistant comprehensive exercise form library
metadata.personality: Lethal Gentleman - direct, efficient, no-nonsense coaching with dry wit

context.equipment: Home gym - dumbbells, kettlebells, bench, resistance bands, foam roller

usage_notes.voice_response: Keep responses concise for voice - setup + 2-3 key cues + main mistake
usage_notes.pain_rule: ALL exercises: if pain >3/10, stop and modify or skip
usage_notes.tempo_default: Controlled movement always - rushing is for amateurs

goblet_squat.name: Goblet Squat
goblet_squat.setup: Hold weight at chest height with elbows tucked. Feet shoulder-width or slightly wider, toes turned out 15-30 degrees.
execution: Big breath into belly, brace core like you're about to get punched
Break at hips AND knees together - don't just push hips back
Push knees out in same direction as toes, don't let them cave
Lower until thighs parallel or just below - elbows between knees at bottom
Drive through whole foot to stand, squeeze glutes at top
cues: Spread the floor with your feet - creates hip tension
Proud chest, weight stays glued to sternum
Sit down between your legs, not back behind them
Think about pushing the floor away as you stand

common_mistakes.mistake: Weight shifts to toes / heels rise
common_mistakes.fix: Drive through whole foot. If mobility is the issue, elevate heels on a 1-inch plate or wedge.
Screw feet into floor, actively push knees out. Consider a resistance band above knees as a cue.

common_mistakes.mistake: Torso tips forward / lower back rounds
common_mistakes.fix: Keep chest up, elbows high. Weight acts as counterbalance - use it.

goblet_squat.breathing: Inhale at top, hold breath and brace during descent, exhale forcefully as you drive up

modifications.easier: Box squat - sit to a bench or box behind you for depth reference
modifications.harder: Pause 2-3 seconds at bottom, or add slow 4-second descent
modifications.ankle_friendly: Elevate heels 1-2 inches on plates or squat wedge

goblet_squat.phase1_notes: Perfect for Phase 1 - teaches squat mechanics with lighter load. Elevate heels if ankle dorsiflexion is limited.

rdl.name: Romanian Deadlift
rdl.setup: Stand tall, feet hip-width, weights held at thighs. Slight bend in knees that STAYS FIXED throughout.
execution: Unlock knees slightly - this angle doesn't change during the lift
Initiate by pushing hips BACK, not by bending forward
Let weights slide down thighs - keep them close
Lower until you feel strong hamstring stretch - stop before back rounds
Drive hips forward to stand, squeeze glutes hard at top
cues: Imagine closing a car door with your arse
Hips back like someone's pulling you by a belt
Weights paint your thighs - never lose contact
Neutral spine is non-negotiable - stop when it wants to round

common_mistakes.mistake: Turning it into a squat - bending knees too much
common_mistakes.fix: Set slight knee bend at start and FREEZE it. The movement is a hip hinge, not a squat.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding lower back to get more range
common_mistakes.fix: Your range is determined by hamstring flexibility. Stop when spine wants to flex.
Engage lats, pull weights into thighs. Think about bending the bar around your legs.

rdl.breathing: Breath in at top, brace core, hold during descent, exhale as you drive hips forward

modifications.easier: Use blocks or plates as targets - tap them at bottom for feedback
modifications.harder: Slow 4-second descent, 2-second pause at bottom stretch
modifications.single_leg: Single-leg RDL for balance and asymmetry correction

rdl.phase1_notes: Essential hip hinge pattern. Use tempo to ingrain proper mechanics.

floor_press.name: Dumbbell Floor Press
floor_press.setup: Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat. Dumbbells at chest height, elbows on floor at 45-degree angle to torso - NOT flared at 90 degrees.
execution: Squeeze shoulder blades together, press them into floor
Grip dumbbells tight, wrists neutral - not bent back
Press up and slightly in - weights meet above chest, not face
Lower with control until upper arms touch floor - don't bounce
Brief pause on floor, then press again
cues: 45-degree elbow angle - protects your shoulder
Drive shoulder blades into the floor
Squeeze glutes and brace core for stability
Control the descent - floor is not a trampoline

common_mistakes.mistake: Elbows flared at 90 degrees to body
common_mistakes.fix: Tuck to 45 degrees. This is shoulder-safe pressing - critical with your rotator cuff.
Touch floor gently, pause, then press. The pause removes momentum.
Squeeze glutes, press lower back toward floor.

floor_press.breathing: Inhale as you lower, exhale as you press

modifications.easier: Lighter weights, focus on slow negatives
modifications.neutral_grip: Palms facing each other - even more shoulder friendly

floor_press.phase1_notes: YOUR go-to pressing movement. Floor limits range of motion - protects shoulder. 45-degree elbows are mandatory with your rotator cuff situation.

chest_supported_row.name: Chest-Supported Row
chest_supported_row.setup: Set bench to 30-45 degrees. Lie chest on pad, feet planted firmly. Let arms hang straight down with dumbbells, head neutral looking at floor.
execution: Keep chest pressed into bench throughout - no lifting up
Initiate row by driving elbows back and up toward ceiling
Squeeze shoulder blades together at top - hold for a beat
Lower with control - full arm extension at bottom
Arms travel at slight angle toward hips, not straight out
cues: Elbows lead the way - think puppeteer pulling strings attached to elbows
Row to your hips, not your armpits
Squeeze shoulder blades like you're cracking a walnut between them
Chest stays glued to bench - if it lifts, weight is too heavy

common_mistakes.mistake: Lifting chest off bench to get more range
common_mistakes.fix: Keep chest planted. If you need to lift off, the weight is too heavy. Ego down.
Pull shoulder blades DOWN and BACK. Think about putting them in your back pockets.
Slow and controlled. 2 seconds up, squeeze, 2 seconds down. No exceptions.
Angle elbows toward hips for lat focus. Wide elbows shift to upper back only.

chest_supported_row.breathing: Exhale as you row up, inhale as you lower

modifications.wider_grip: Elbows out wider for more upper back and rear delt focus
modifications.neutral_grip: Palms facing each other - easier on elbows
modifications.single_arm: One arm at a time for asymmetry correction

chest_supported_row.phase1_notes: Safe for your shoulder because bench supports you - no strain on rotator cuff from stabilizing. Build your back without aggravating the shoulder.

kettlebell_swing.name: Kettlebell Swing
kettlebell_swing.setup: KB on floor about 12 inches in front of you. Feet slightly wider than shoulder width. Hinge at hips to grip handle with both hands.
execution: Hike KB back between legs - high on inner thighs, wrists touching
Snap hips forward explosively - this is where power comes from
Let arms float up naturally - chest height max for Russian swing
At top: standing tall, glutes squeezed HARD, core braced like a plank
Wait until KB starts falling, then hinge at LAST second - play chicken with your hips
cues: It's a hip hinge, not a squat - your arms are just ropes holding the bell
Hips do 100% of the work - arms do 0%
Squeeze glutes like you're cracking a walnut at top
Plank at the top - don't lean back
Attack your zipper with your wrists on the backswing

common_mistakes.mistake: Turning it into a squat - knees bending too much
common_mistakes.fix: Keep shins vertical. Hinge at hips, don't squat down. Put a foam roller between feet - if you hit it, you're squatting.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using arms to lift the bell
common_mistakes.fix: Arms are just hooks. If your shoulders are burning, your hips aren't doing the work. Go heavier - forces proper form.
Stand tall like a plank. Squeeze glutes to STOP the movement, don't hyperextend spine.

common_mistakes.mistake: Hinging too early on the way down
common_mistakes.fix: Play chicken - wait until bell is almost at your hips before hinging back. Early hinge = back pain.

kettlebell_swing.breathing: Sharp exhale at top (like a punch), inhale on backswing

modifications.easier: Dead-stop swings - set bell down between each rep to reset
modifications.towel_swing: Loop towel through handle - forces you to use hips, can't cheat with arms

kettlebell_swing.phase1_notes: Powerful hip hinge pattern. Start with dead-stop single swings until form is locked. Do NOT let ego drive weight selection.

plank.name: Plank
plank.setup: Forearms on floor, elbows directly under shoulders. Toes tucked, legs straight. Body forms straight line from head to heels.
execution: Squeeze glutes - this protects lower back
Brace core like you're about to get punched in the gut
Push forearms into floor - creates lat engagement
Tuck pelvis slightly - eliminates low back sag
Eyes on floor, neutral neck - not looking forward
cues: Squeeze your arse - this is non-negotiable
Think about pulling elbows toward toes (they won't move, but the intent creates tension)
Straight line from ears to ankles - broomstick test
Breathe. Don't hold your breath like an idiot.

common_mistakes.fix: Squeeze glutes harder. If they still sag, you're done - end the set. Quality over quantity.
You're not doing downward dog. Lower hips until body is straight line.
Neutral neck. Look at floor between forearms. Ears in line with shoulders.
Breathe normally. Core should stay braced while breathing - that's the skill you're building.

plank.breathing: Normal, continuous breathing - maintain brace while breathing

modifications.easier: From knees, or elevated hands on bench
modifications.harder: Add arm reaches, leg lifts, or body saw movement

plank.phase1_notes: Quality over time. 30 seconds with perfect form beats 2 minutes of garbage form. End set when form breaks.

dead_bug.name: Dead Bug
dead_bug.setup: Lie on back, arms pointing to ceiling. Legs in tabletop - hips and knees at 90 degrees. Press lower back INTO floor - no gap.
execution: Press lower back firmly into floor - this is the key
Slowly lower opposite arm and leg toward floor
Arm goes overhead, leg extends straight out
Stop BEFORE lower back lifts off floor
Return to start with control, switch sides
cues: Flatten your lower back into the mat - imagine you're squashing a blueberry
Move slow - this isn't a race
If back lifts off floor, you've gone too far
Think about resisting your limbs moving - not just moving them

common_mistakes.fix: Reduce range of motion. Only go as far as you can while keeping back flat. That's your working range.
2-3 seconds each direction. Control is the point. Speed kills the benefit.
Exhale as you extend limbs, inhale as you return. Breathing while bracing is the skill.
OPPOSITE arm and leg. Right arm with left leg. Cross-body pattern.

dead_bug.breathing: Exhale as limbs extend away, inhale as they return

modifications.easier: Move only legs (arms stay up), or only arms (legs stay in tabletop)
modifications.harder: Hold light dumbbells, or add resistance band around feet
modifications.stability_ball: Press ball between one knee and one hand - maintains tension

dead_bug.phase1_notes: Foundation exercise. Teaches core bracing while limbs move - exactly what you need for all other lifts. Do this daily as warmup.

bird_dog.name: Bird Dog
bird_dog.setup: Hands and knees position. Hands under shoulders, knees under hips. Flat back - spine neutral. Eyes looking at floor.
execution: Engage core and squeeze glutes before moving
Slowly extend opposite arm and leg simultaneously
Reach arm forward, leg back - both parallel to floor
Hold for 1-2 seconds at full extension
Return with control, switch sides
cues: Imagine balancing a glass of water on your lower back - don't let it spill
Reach LONG - arm forward, leg back, like someone's stretching you
Hips and shoulders stay SQUARE - no rotation
Squeeze glute of extending leg HARD

common_mistakes.fix: Engage core BEFORE moving limbs. If back moves, range of motion is too big.
Keep knee of extending leg pointing DOWN at floor. Don't let it rotate outward.
Slow and controlled. 2 seconds out, hold, 2 seconds back. This builds control, not cardio.
Eyes on floor. Neutral neck in line with spine. Not looking at the wall ahead.

bird_dog.breathing: Exhale as you extend, inhale as you return

modifications.easier: Move only arm OR only leg - not both together
modifications.harder: Add 3-second hold at top, or loop resistance band around feet
modifications.elevated: Hands on bench for more challenge to stability

bird_dog.phase1_notes: Part of Stuart McGill's 'Big 3' for back health. Essential for your program. Teaches spine stability while limbs move - carry over to every other exercise.

glute_bridge.name: Glute Bridge
glute_bridge.setup: Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat on floor hip-width apart. Feet close enough that fingertips can touch heels. Arms at sides, palms down.
execution: Push through heels - not toes
Squeeze glutes to lift hips off floor
Lift until body forms straight line from knees to shoulders
Squeeze glutes HARD at top - 1 second hold
Lower with control - don't just drop
cues: Drive through heels - toes can even lift slightly
Squeeze glutes like you're pinching a coin between your cheeks
Straight line from knees to shoulders - no excessive arch
Don't push through lower back - push through glutes

common_mistakes.mistake: Pushing through toes instead of heels
common_mistakes.fix: Lift toes off floor slightly if needed. Heel drive activates glutes properly.
Stop when body is straight line. If you feel it in lower back, you've gone too high.
The squeeze is the point. Without it, hamstrings take over. Squeeze like your life depends on it.
Bring feet closer. Should be able to touch heels with fingertips from starting position.

glute_bridge.breathing: Exhale as you lift, inhale as you lower

modifications.easier: Smaller range of motion, feet wider
modifications.harder: Single leg, or add band around knees, or add weight on hips
modifications.march: At top, march knees up alternating - adds stability challenge

glute_bridge.phase1_notes: Perfect warmup exercise. Activates glutes before squats, deadlifts, and any lower body work. Do 10-15 in every warmup.

cat_cow.name: Cat-Cow
cat_cow.setup: Hands and knees. Hands under shoulders, knees under hips. Start with neutral spine.
execution: COW: Inhale, drop belly toward floor, lift tailbone and chest, eyes forward
Initiate from pelvis - tailbone tilts up first, then wave travels up spine
CAT: Exhale, round spine toward ceiling, tuck tailbone, chin to chest
Again, initiate from pelvis - tailbone tucks first, then wave up spine
Move slowly between positions - feel each vertebra
cues: Move from the pelvis first - let the wave travel up
Slow and controlled - this isn't a race
Feel each segment of your spine moving
Don't force end ranges - go only where comfortable

common_mistakes.fix: 3-4 seconds each direction. The slow movement is what mobilizes the spine.

common_mistakes.mistake: Only moving at waist / lower back
common_mistakes.fix: Move through entire spine - from tailbone to skull. Include neck in the movement.
Inhale to cow (belly drops), exhale to cat (back rounds). Breath drives movement.
If any position hurts, reduce range. Only move through pain-free range.

cat_cow.breathing: Inhale for cow (arch), exhale for cat (round)

modifications.seated: Can do in chair - hands on thighs, same spinal movement
modifications.standing: Hands on wall - similar movement pattern

cat_cow.phase1_notes: Do 10 reps every morning and before every workout. Wakes up the spine, prepares it for movement. Non-negotiable daily mobility.

worlds_greatest_stretch.name: World's Greatest Stretch
worlds_greatest_stretch.setup: Start in high plank position or standing.
execution: Step right foot outside right hand into deep lunge
Left knee can rest on floor for support if needed
Place left hand firmly on floor for stability
Rotate torso to right, reach right arm to ceiling
Eyes follow right hand - feel thoracic rotation
Return hand to floor, step back to plank, switch sides
cues: Front knee tracks over ankle - not past toes
Twist comes from mid-back (thoracic), not lower back
Keep back leg active - don't just let it hang there
Really reach for the ceiling - maximize rotation

common_mistakes.fix: Push knee OUT toward pinky toe side. Engages glutes and protects knee.
3-5 seconds per position. This is a stretch, not cardio. Slow wins.
Lower back stays stable. Rotation comes from upper back. Think about opening chest to sky.
Drop back hip down and forward. That's where the hip flexor stretch comes from.

worlds_greatest_stretch.breathing: Exhale as you rotate up, inhale as you return

modifications.easier: Back knee down on mat, use yoga block under hand
modifications.add_hamstring: After rotation, rock back and straighten front leg - stretch hamstring

worlds_greatest_stretch.phase1_notes: If you only do ONE warmup stretch, this is it. Hits ankles, hips, thoracic spine all at once. 5 per side before every workout.

band_pull_apart.name: Band Pull-Apart
band_pull_apart.setup: Stand tall, hold band in front at shoulder height. Arms straight, palms down, band taut but not stretched.
execution: Keep arms straight throughout
Pull band apart by squeezing shoulder blades together
Drive hands out to sides until band touches chest
Squeeze shoulder blades HARD at end position - 1 second hold
Return slowly with control - don't let band snap back
cues: Pull with your back, not your arms - elbows stay straight
Shoulder blades go DOWN and BACK - not UP toward ears
Control the return - eccentric is half the exercise
Think about trying to touch your shoulder blades together

common_mistakes.fix: Lock elbows straight. If you can't complete rep, use lighter band.
Actively depress shoulders DOWN before pulling. Shoulders stay away from ears.
Control the return. Eccentric strengthening is crucial for shoulder health.

band_pull_apart.breathing: Exhale as you pull apart, inhale as you return

modifications.easier: Lighter band, smaller range of motion
modifications.higher: Pull to face level for upper traps emphasis
modifications.lower: Pull to belly level for different angle

band_pull_apart.phase1_notes: CRITICAL for your shoulder rehab. 15-20 reps in warmup, 20 reps in shoulder rehab block. Builds posterior shoulder strength that counteracts internal rotation dominance.

face_pull.name: Face Pull
face_pull.setup: Band attached at face height (door anchor, pull-up bar). Hold ends with overhand grip, arms extended, palms facing down.
execution: Pull band toward face - elbows go high and wide
As you pull, rotate hands outward - finish with thumbs pointing back
End position: hands beside ears, elbows high, external rotation
Squeeze shoulder blades together at end - hold 1 second
Return with control
cues: Pull to your ears, not your chin
Elbows stay HIGH - above wrist level
End with external rotation - thumbs pointing behind you
Don't lean back to cheat - stay tall

common_mistakes.fix: Pull to EAR level. This is what hits the external rotators.
Rotate hands back at top - like you're doing a double bicep pose. This is the money position.
Stay vertical. If you need to lean, use lighter band.

face_pull.breathing: Exhale as you pull, inhale as you return
face_pull.phase1_notes: Essential for rotator cuff health. The external rotation at top specifically targets the muscles you need to rehab. Do these 3x weekly minimum. THE HEALER exercise.

side_lying_external_rotation.name: Side-Lying External Rotation
side_lying_external_rotation.setup: Lie on uninvolved side. Involved arm on top, elbow bent 90 degrees, elbow pinned to side with rolled towel if needed.
execution: Keep elbow PINNED to side throughout
Rotate forearm UP toward ceiling - external rotation
Go only as high as comfortable - don't force
SLOW 4-second lowering (eccentric) - this is where the magic happens
Return to start, repeat
cues: Elbow stays glued to your side - it doesn't move
The SLOW lowering is the rehab - don't drop it fast
Pain-free range only - stop before pain starts
Think about your forearm as a door hinge rotating on your elbow

common_mistakes.fix: Put rolled towel under elbow - keeps it in correct position.
This is rehab, not strength training. 1-2kg max. Control beats load.
4-second eccentric minimum. The slow lowering is what heals the tendon.
STOP before pain. Work in pain-free range. Painful rehab is counterproductive.

side_lying_external_rotation.phase1_notes: THE exercise for rotator cuff rehab. Eccentric loading is proven for tendon healing. 3 sets of 10-15 daily. Very light weight - 1-2kg. Slow 4-second lowering.

doorframe_external_rotation.name: Doorframe External Rotation Isometric
doorframe_external_rotation.setup: Stand in doorframe. Elbow bent 90 degrees, pinned to side. Back of wrist against door frame.
execution: Push back of wrist INTO doorframe - external rotation force
Use submaximal effort - 30-50% max, not all-out
Hold for 45 seconds
Breathe normally throughout
Release, rest, repeat
cues: Gentle push - not maximum effort
No pain - if it hurts, reduce force
Elbow stays glued to side
Keep breathing - don't hold breath

common_mistakes.fix: Submaximal effort only. This is activation and neural drive, not strength test.
Keep elbow pinned to side. Put towel under elbow if needed.
Normal breathing. Breath holding spikes blood pressure unnecessarily.

doorframe_external_rotation.duration: 45 seconds per hold, 2 holds per session
doorframe_external_rotation.phase1_notes: Pain-killing isometric. Do BEFORE workouts to 'wake up' rotator cuff. Also good when shoulder is cranky - activates the muscles without aggravating tendon.

towel_crush.name: Towel Crush
towel_crush.setup: Stand or sit. Roll small towel. Place between elbow and side body. Arm at side, elbow bent 90 degrees.
execution: Squeeze elbow into towel/body - adduction force
Hold for 10 seconds
Release, rest 2-3 seconds
Repeat 5 times
cues: Moderate squeeze - not maximum effort
Should feel front of shoulder working
No pain - if painful, reduce force

common_mistakes.fix: 50% effort max. This is activation, not strength training.

towel_crush.duration: 10 seconds per squeeze, 5 squeezes per set
towel_crush.phase1_notes: Pairs with doorframe ER. Activates anterior shoulder to balance the posterior work. Part of your shoulder rehab block.

scapular_wall_slide.name: Scapular Wall Slide
scapular_wall_slide.setup: Stand with back flat against wall. Feet few inches from wall. Arms at sides, elbows and backs of hands against wall.
execution: Slide arms up wall - keep elbows and hands touching wall
Go as high as you can while maintaining wall contact
At top, push hands INTO wall slightly - activates serratus
Slide back down with control
Keep entire back flat against wall throughout
cues: Elbows AND hands stay on wall - both points of contact
If something comes off wall, that's your current range limit
Slight push into wall at top - serratus activation
Core stays braced - no arching away from wall

common_mistakes.fix: Brace core, flatten lower back into wall. If arch happens, reduce range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Elbows or hands losing wall contact
common_mistakes.fix: That's your limit. Only go as high as you can maintain contact.
Keep shoulders DOWN. Range is limited - that's fine. Don't compensate.

scapular_wall_slide.breathing: Exhale as you slide up, inhale as you slide down
scapular_wall_slide.phase1_notes: Teaches proper scapular mechanics. Critical for shoulder health. If you can't do this clean, your shoulder blade isn't moving properly.

hip_flexor_stretch.name: Hip Flexor Stretch
hip_flexor_stretch.setup: Half-kneeling position. Back knee on pad, front foot flat on floor. Torso upright.
execution: Tuck pelvis UNDER - posterior pelvic tilt
Squeeze glute of back leg HARD
Shift weight gently forward while maintaining tuck
You should feel stretch in front of back hip
Hold for 60 seconds minimum
cues: Tuck tailbone UNDER - this is what unlocks the stretch
If you don't squeeze glute, you're not stretching hip flexor properly
Don't lean forward at waist - stay upright
Stretch is in FRONT of hip, not lower back

common_mistakes.mistake: Arching lower back to feel stretch
common_mistakes.fix: That's lower back extension, not hip flexor stretch. Tuck pelvis, squeeze glute.
Stay upright. Lean is cheating - reduces stretch on hip flexor.
Glute squeeze is mandatory. It's what creates reciprocal inhibition of the hip flexor.

hip_flexor_stretch.breathing: Deep, relaxed breathing - no breath holding

modifications.couch_stretch: Back foot elevated on couch/wall behind you - more intense
modifications.standing: Modified lunge position if kneeling is uncomfortable

hip_flexor_stretch.phase1_notes: Tight hip flexors are probably contributing to your issues. 60 seconds per side daily. Do in rehab block AND cooldown.

single_leg_balance.name: Single Leg Balance
single_leg_balance.setup: Stand tall on one leg. Other knee lifted to hip height. Arms wherever helps balance.
execution: Stand on one leg - foot pointing straight ahead
Slight bend in standing knee - not locked out
Engage core, squeeze glute of standing leg
Hold position - minimize wobbling
Eyes forward on fixed point
cues: Root through whole foot - tripod stance (heel, big toe, little toe)
Standing knee tracks over toes
Hip stays level - don't let it drop on lifted side
Breathe normally - don't hold breath

common_mistakes.fix: Slight bend. Locked knee reduces proprioceptive feedback.

common_mistakes.mistake: Hip drops on lifted leg side
common_mistakes.fix: Engage glute med on standing leg. Keep pelvis level.

common_mistakes.mistake: Weight shifts to edge of foot
common_mistakes.fix: Spread through whole foot. Rolling = ankle/hip weakness.

progression.eyes_open_unstable: Pillow, foam pad, or wobble cushion

single_leg_balance.phase1_notes: GATE 1 REQUIREMENT: 60 seconds eyes open, 30 seconds eyes closed. Essential for ankle rehab. Train daily.

heel_raises.name: Single Leg Heel Raises
heel_raises.setup: Stand on one leg, ball of foot on edge of step (optional). Hand on wall for light balance support only.
execution: Push through ball of foot to raise heel as high as possible
Pause at top - full contraction
Lower slowly with control (3-4 seconds)
Go below step level if using step (full stretch)
Use hand for balance only - not to push yourself up
cues: Push up through big toe, not rolling to outside of foot
Straight ankle - don't let it wobble side to side
Full range of motion - bottom to top
Control the eccentric - lowering builds strength

common_mistakes.fix: Light fingertip touch only. The calf does the work.
Rise onto tiptoes - full plantar flexion.
Control the lowering - this eccentric portion is crucial for tendon health.

heel_raises.breathing: Exhale as you rise, inhale as you lower
heel_raises.phase1_notes: GATE 1 REQUIREMENT: 25 reps each leg, LSI â‰¥90%. Critical for ankle return to sport.

ankle_cars.name: Ankle CARs
ankle_cars.setup: Seated or standing (holding support). Lift one foot off ground.
execution: Point toes down (plantar flexion)
Roll foot inward (inversion)
Pull toes up (dorsiflexion)
Roll foot outward (eversion)
Complete full circles - both directions
cues: Make the BIGGEST circle possible
Move through every degree of the range
Slow and controlled - no jerky movements
End range is where the work happens - push into it gently

common_mistakes.fix: Make them HUGE. Push into end ranges. That's the whole point.
Keep leg still. Only the ankle moves.
5-10 seconds per full circle. Slow reveals where you're restricted.

ankle_cars.phase1_notes: Daily ankle maintenance. Restores and maintains full ankle range. Do every morning and before any lower body work.

eccentric_calf_raises.name: Eccentric Calf Raises
eccentric_calf_raises.setup: Stand on step, balls of both feet on edge. Rise up on toes using both legs.
execution: Rise up on toes using BOTH legs - this is the easy part
At top, lift one foot off step
Lower SLOWLY on single leg over 3-5 seconds
Go below step level - full stretch on achilles
Put other foot back down, rise on both, repeat
cues: The LOWERING is the exercise - go slow
Control through entire range - no dropping
Full stretch at bottom - heel below step level
Rise on two, lower on one

common_mistakes.fix: 3-5 seconds down. The eccentric loading is the rehab stimulus.
Full stretch is important. Heel must drop below step.

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to rise on one leg
common_mistakes.fix: Rise on TWO legs. Only the lowering is single-leg. This is eccentric protocol.

eccentric_calf_raises.breathing: Inhale at top, exhale during lowering
eccentric_calf_raises.reps: 15 reps per leg, 2-3 sets, daily for tendon rehab
eccentric_calf_raises.phase1_notes: Gold standard for achilles/calf tendon rehab. The slow eccentric loading stimulates tendon remodeling. Part of your daily ankle work.

banded_ankle_mobilization.name: Banded Ankle Mobilization
banded_ankle_mobilization.setup: Loop heavy band around fixed point at ankle height. Step into band so it wraps around front of ankle. Step forward to create tension.
execution: Band pulls ankle joint backward (posterior glide)
Drive knee forward over toes - into dorsiflexion
Hold at end range for 15-30 seconds
Oscillate gently in and out of end range
Band distraction creates space in joint for movement
cues: Band should pull ankle BACK, not up
Keep heel DOWN on floor
Drive knee forward AND slightly out
Gentle oscillations, not forcing

common_mistakes.fix: Keep heel planted. If it lifts, you're not mobilizing the ankle.
Band should be at ankle crease, not on shin.

banded_ankle_mobilization.phase1_notes: Key for improving dorsiflexion. If your ankle dorsiflexion is limited, this is how you improve it. Do before any squat work.

plantar_fascia_ball_roll.name: Plantar Fascia Ball Roll
plantar_fascia_ball_roll.setup: Stand or sit. Place ball under arch of foot.
execution: Apply moderate pressure through foot onto ball
Roll ball from heel to toes
Pause on tender spots for 10-15 seconds
Cover entire sole - arch, heel, ball of foot
60 seconds per foot
cues: Moderate pressure - should feel 'good pain', not agony
Slow rolling - not just skating over surface
Spend extra time on tight/tender spots
Breathe and relax into it

common_mistakes.fix: Back off. Should be uncomfortable but not agonizing.
Slow down. Let the ball work into the tissue.

plantar_fascia_ball_roll.phase1_notes: Daily foot maintenance. Keeps plantar fascia happy. Do first thing in the morning before standing.

toe_yoga.name: Toe Yoga
toe_yoga.setup: Barefoot, standing or seated. Feet flat on floor.
execution: Lift big toe only while pressing other 4 toes into floor
Then press big toe down and lift other 4 toes
Alternate back and forth
Keep foot stationary - only toes move
cues: Isolate the movements - this is harder than it sounds
Don't let foot roll or move
Go slowly - it's a motor control exercise

common_mistakes.fix: Anchor the foot. Only toes should move.
Use hand to help initially. Build the neural pathway.

toe_yoga.phase1_notes: Builds foot control and intrinsic muscle strength. Supports ankle stability from the ground up.

short_foot_exercise.name: Short Foot Exercise
short_foot_exercise.setup: Barefoot, standing or seated. Feet flat on floor.
execution: Keep toes relaxed and flat on floor
Draw ball of foot toward heel WITHOUT curling toes
This 'domes' the arch - shortens the foot
Hold for 10 seconds
Release and repeat
cues: Toes stay FLAT - no gripping or curling
Think about 'shortening' your foot
Arch lifts up, foot gets shorter
Should feel deep foot muscles working

common_mistakes.fix: Toes must stay flat and relaxed. The arch lifts from within.
Start seated, foot on towel. Try to 'gather' towel without curling toes.

short_foot_exercise.phase1_notes: Activates intrinsic foot muscles that support the arch. Foundation for ankle stability. Do daily.

calf_stretch_wall.name: Wall Calf Stretch
calf_stretch_wall.setup: Face wall, hands on wall at shoulder height. Step one foot back, keeping heel on floor.
execution: Back leg straight, heel pressed into floor
Lean into wall, keeping back leg straight
Feel stretch in upper calf of back leg
Hold 45-60 seconds
For soleus: bend back knee slightly while keeping heel down
cues: Heel must stay DOWN - no cheating
Back leg stays STRAIGHT for gastroc
Lean from ankles, not waist
Both feet pointing forward

common_mistakes.fix: Keep heel down. If it lifts, step closer to wall.
Straight leg targets gastrocnemius. Bent knee targets soleus. Know which you're doing.

calf_stretch_wall.phase1_notes: Essential for ankle dorsiflexion. Tight calves limit ankle mobility. Do daily, plus after any calf work.

thoracic_extension_foam_roller.name: Thoracic Extension on Foam Roller
thoracic_extension_foam_roller.setup: Lie on foam roller placed horizontally across mid-back. Knees bent, feet flat. Hands behind head to support neck.
execution: Start with roller at bra-line level (mid-thoracic)
Let upper back extend over roller - don't force
Exhale and relax into extension
Move roller up slightly, repeat at new segment
Work from mid-back to upper back
cues: Keep butt on floor - no bridging up
Support head with hands - don't strain neck
Extend from mid-back, NOT lower back
Breathe and relax - don't fight it

common_mistakes.fix: Lower back stays neutral. Only thoracic spine moves. Keep abs engaged.
Exhale into the extension. Breath helps release tension.
This isn't rolling. It's targeted extension at each segment. Move roller, then extend.

thoracic_extension_foam_roller.breathing: Exhale as you extend over roller
thoracic_extension_foam_roller.reps: 5 breaths at each position, 3-4 positions up the spine
thoracic_extension_foam_roller.phase1_notes: Essential for posture and shoulder health. Thoracic stiffness causes shoulder compensation. Do daily in rehab block.

chin_tuck.name: Chin Tuck
chin_tuck.setup: Sitting or standing tall. Shoulders relaxed. Looking straight ahead.
execution: Draw chin straight BACK (not down)
Imagine making a double chin
Head moves back, not tilting
Hold 5-10 seconds
Release and repeat
cues: Make a 'double chin' - that's the movement
Head slides back on a shelf - doesn't tilt
Gentle stretch at base of skull
Don't tuck chin to chest - horizontal movement

common_mistakes.fix: Eyes stay level. Head moves horizontally back, not down.
No extension. Pure retraction - chin slides back.

chin_tuck.phase1_notes: Counteracts forward head posture. Do every few hours if you work at a computer. Part of posture reset block.

pigeon_stretch.name: Pigeon Stretch
pigeon_stretch.setup: Start in all-fours. Bring one knee forward behind same-side wrist. Extend other leg straight back.
execution: Front shin angled across body (more angle = more intense)
Back leg extends straight behind
Square hips toward floor as much as possible
Stay upright or fold forward over front leg
Hold for 90 seconds minimum
cues: Front shin doesn't need to be parallel to front edge of mat - angle is individual
Keep hips square - don't let back hip rotate open
Breathe and sink into stretch over time
Stretch should be in glute/hip of front leg

common_mistakes.fix: Square hips. Use yoga block under front hip if needed for support.
Keep front foot flexed to protect knee. Reduce angle of front shin.

pigeon_stretch.phase1_notes: Deep glute and hip stretch. Essential cooldown. Hold for full 90 seconds - the magic happens after 60 seconds.

lat_stretch.name: Lat Stretch
lat_stretch.setup: Stand next to doorframe or pole. Grab with near hand overhead. Step feet away.
execution: Grab overhead anchor with one hand
Step feet away from anchor
Let body hang sideways - stretching lat
Lean hips away from anchor to increase stretch
Hold 60 seconds
cues: Feel stretch along side of back and ribcage
Push hips AWAY from anchor
Let shoulder stretch overhead
Breathe into the stretch
lat_stretch.phase1_notes: Essential if your lats are tight. Tight lats affect shoulder overhead motion. Part of cooldown.

hamstring_stretch.name: Hamstring Stretch
hamstring_stretch.setup: Seated on floor. One leg extended, other leg bent with foot against inner thigh of straight leg. Sit tall.
execution: Hinge at hips - not waist
Reach toward foot of extended leg
Keep back FLAT as you fold - don't round
Stop when you feel stretch in back of thigh
Hold 60 seconds
cues: Lead with chest, not head
Flat back - don't round to reach further
Stretch is in hamstring, not lower back
Use strap around foot if can't reach

common_mistakes.fix: Keep back flat. Less range with flat back is better than more range with rounded back.
Static hold only. Bouncing triggers stretch reflex and reduces effectiveness.

hamstring_stretch.phase1_notes: Your hamstring flexibility affects hip hinge (RDL) quality. Stretch them after every workout.

pec_stretch.name: Pec Stretch
pec_stretch.setup: Stand in doorway. Place forearm against doorframe, elbow at shoulder height, 90-degree bend in elbow.
execution: Forearm against doorframe, elbow at shoulder height
Step through doorway with same-side foot
Rotate torso AWAY from arm - feel chest stretch
Don't lean forward - stay upright
Hold 60 seconds
cues: Elbow at shoulder height or slightly higher
Step THROUGH and PAST the doorframe
Turn body away - stretch is in chest, not shoulder
Should feel stretch across chest, not front of shoulder

common_mistakes.mistake: Feeling stretch in front of shoulder only
common_mistakes.fix: Adjust elbow height and rotation angle. If shoulder hurts, back off.
Stay upright. Step through further if needed.

pec_stretch.phase1_notes: Important for shoulder health. Tight pecs pull shoulders forward. Stretch after any pressing work.

spine_decompression_hang.name: Spine Decompression Hang
spine_decompression_hang.setup: Grip pull-up bar with overhand grip, shoulder width. Let body hang freely. Feet can touch floor lightly if needed.
execution: Grip bar firmly
Let body hang - allow spine to decompress
Keep shoulders engaged (not just hanging from joints)
Relax everything else - let gravity stretch you
Hold as long as comfortable
cues: Relax your lower body - let it hang heavy
Active shoulders - don't just hang from joints
Feel space being created between vertebrae
Breathe deeply and relax

common_mistakes.fix: Keep slight shoulder engagement. Think about 'pulling shoulder blades down' slightly.
Stay still. The decompression requires stillness.

spine_decompression_hang.phase1_notes: Great end-of-workout cooldown. Decompresses spine after loaded exercises. Grip work bonus. Be gentle with shoulder - stop if painful.

quick_reference.shoulder_safe_pressing: Neutral grip floor press with 45-degree elbow angle
quick_reference.ankle_mobility_help: Elevate heels for goblet squats and split squats if dorsiflexion limited

voice_response_format.medium: {name}. {setup} Execution: {execution[0:3]}. Key cues: {cues[0:3]}. Common mistake: {common_mistakes[0].mistake} - fix: {common_mistakes[0].fix}
voice_response_format.full: Return all fields formatted for voice
